text_entry: That Alexander Iden, an esquire of Kent,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Took odds to combat a poor famishd man.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Oppose thy steadfast-gazing eyes to mine,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: See if thou canst outface me with thy looks:

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Set limb to limb, and thou art far the lesser;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy hand is but a finger to my fist,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy leg a stick compared with this truncheon;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: My foot shall fight with all the strength thou hast;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And if mine arm be heaved in the air,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Thy grave is diggd already in the earth.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: As for words, whose greatness answers words,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Let this my sword report what speech forbears.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: By my valour, the most complete champion that ever I

speaker: CADE
text_entry: heard! Steel, if thou turn the edge, or cut not out

speaker: CADE
text_entry: the burly-boned clown in chines of beef ere thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: sleep in thy sheath, I beseech God on my knees thou

speaker: CADE
text_entry: mayst be turned to hobnails.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Here they fight. CADE falls

speaker: CADE
text_entry: O, I am slain! famine and no other hath slain me:

speaker: CADE
text_entry: let ten thousand devils come against me, and give me

speaker: CADE
text_entry: but the ten meals I have lost, and Ill defy them

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all. Wither, garden; and be henceforth a

speaker: CADE
text_entry: burying-place to all that do dwell in this house,

speaker: CADE
text_entry: because the unconquered soul of Cade is fled.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Ist Cade that I have slain, that monstrous traitor?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Sword, I will hollow thee for this thy deed,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And hang thee oer my tomb when I am dead:

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Neer shall this blood be wiped from thy point;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: But thou shalt wear it as a heralds coat,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: To emblaze the honour that thy master got.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Iden, farewell, and be proud of thy victory. Tell

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Kent from me, she hath lost her best man, and exhort

speaker: CADE
text_entry: all the world to be cowards; for I, that never

speaker: CADE
text_entry: feared any, am vanquished by famine, not by valour.

speaker: CADE
text_entry: Dies

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: How much thou wrongst me, heaven be my judge.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Die, damned wretch, the curse of her that bare thee;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And as I thrust thy body in with my sword,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: So wish I, I might thrust thy soul to hell.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Hence will I drag thee headlong by the heels

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Unto a dunghill which shall be thy grave,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And there cut off thy most ungracious head;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Which I will bear in triumph to the king,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Leaving thy trunk for crows to feed upon.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: SCENE I. Fields between Dartford and Blackheath.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Enter YORK, and his army of Irish, with drum and colours

speaker: YORK
text_entry: From Ireland thus comes York to claim his right,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And pluck the crown from feeble Henrys head:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ring, bells, aloud; burn, bonfires, clear and bright,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To entertain great Englands lawful king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ah! sancta majestas, who would not buy thee dear?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let them obey that know not how to rule;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This hand was made to handle naught but gold.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I cannot give due action to my words,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Except a sword or sceptre balance it:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A sceptre shall it have, have I a soul,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: On which Ill toss the flower-de-luce of France.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whom have we here? Buckingham, to disturb me?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The king hath sent him, sure: I must dissemble.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: York, if thou meanest well, I greet thee well.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Humphrey of Buckingham, I accept thy greeting.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Art thou a messenger, or come of pleasure?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: A messenger from Henry, our dread liege,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To know the reason of these arms in peace;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or why thou, being a subject as I am,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Against thy oath and true allegiance sworn,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Should raise so great a power without his leave,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or dare to bring thy force so near the court.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: [Aside]  Scarce can I speak, my choler is so great:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, I could hew up rocks and fight with flint,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am so angry at these abject terms;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And now, like Ajax Telamonius,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: On sheep or oxen could I spend my fury.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am far better born than is the king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: More like a king, more kingly in my thoughts:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But I must make fair weather yet a while,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Till Henry be more weak and I more strong,--

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Buckingham, I prithee, pardon me,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That I have given no answer all this while;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My mind was troubled with deep melancholy.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The cause why I have brought this army hither

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is to remove proud Somerset from the king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Seditious to his grace and to the state.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That is too much presumption on thy part:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But if thy arms be to no other end,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The king hath yielded unto thy demand:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The Duke of Somerset is in the Tower.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Upon thine honour, is he prisoner?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon mine honour, he is prisoner.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then, Buckingham, I do dismiss my powers.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Soldiers, I thank you all; disperse yourselves;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Meet me to-morrow in St. Georges field,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You shall have pay and every thing you wish.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And let my sovereign, virtuous Henry,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Command my eldest son, nay, all my sons,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As pledges of my fealty and love;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ill send them all as willing as I live:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lands, goods, horse, armour, any thing I have,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is his to use, so Somerset may die.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: York, I commend this kind submission:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We twain will go into his highness tent.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Buckingham, doth York intend no harm to us,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That thus he marcheth with thee arm in arm?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In all submission and humility

speaker: YORK
text_entry: York doth present himself unto your highness.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Then what intends these forces thou dost bring?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To heave the traitor Somerset from hence,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And fight against that monstrous rebel Cade,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Who since I heard to be discomfited.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter IDEN, with CADES head

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: If one so rude and of so mean condition

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: May pass into the presence of a king,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Lo, I present your grace a traitors head,

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: The head of Cade, whom I in combat slew.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The head of Cade! Great God, how just art Thou!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, let me view his visage, being dead,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That living wrought me such exceeding trouble.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tell me, my friend, art thou the man that slew him?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: I was, ant like your majesty.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How art thou calld? and what is thy degree?

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Alexander Iden, thats my name;

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: A poor esquire of Kent, that loves his king.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So please it you, my lord, twere not amiss

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He were created knight for his good service.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Iden, kneel down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: He kneels

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Rise up a knight.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: We give thee for reward a thousand marks,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And will that thou henceforth attend on us.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: May Iden live to merit such a bounty.

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: And never live but true unto his liege!

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Rises

speaker: IDEN
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET and SOMERSET

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: See, Buckingham, Somerset comes with the queen:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Go, bid her hide him quickly from the duke.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For thousand Yorks he shall not hide his head,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But boldly stand and front him to his face.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: How now! is Somerset at liberty?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then, York, unloose thy long-imprisond thoughts,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And let thy tongue be equal with thy heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall I endure the sight of Somerset?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: False king! why hast thou broken faith with me,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Knowing how hardly I can brook abuse?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: King did I call thee? no, thou art not king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Not fit to govern and rule multitudes,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Which darest not, no, nor canst not rule a traitor.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That head of thine doth not become a crown;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thy hand is made to grasp a palmers staff,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And not to grace an awful princely sceptre.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That gold must round engirt these brows of mine,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose smile and frown, like to Achilles spear,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is able with the change to kill and cure.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Here is a hand to hold a sceptre up

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And with the same to act controlling laws.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Give place: by heaven, thou shalt rule no more

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Oer him whom heaven created for thy ruler.

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: O monstrous traitor! I arrest thee, York,

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Of capital treason gainst the king and crown;

speaker: SOMERSET
text_entry: Obey, audacious traitor; kneel for grace.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Wouldst have me kneel? first let me ask of these,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If they can brook I bow a knee to man.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sirrah, call in my sons to be my bail;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit Attendant

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I know, ere they will have me go to ward,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Theyll pawn their swords for my enfranchisement.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Call hither Clifford! bid him come amain,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To say if that the bastard boys of York

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Shall be the surety for their traitor father.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exit BUCKINGHAM

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O blood-besotted Neapolitan,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Outcast of Naples, Englands bloody scourge!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The sons of York, thy betters in their birth,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Shall be their fathers bail; and bane to those

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That for my surety will refuse the boys!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter EDWARD and RICHARD

speaker: YORK
text_entry: See where they come: Ill warrant theyll

speaker: YORK
text_entry: make it good.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter CLIFFORD and YOUNG CLIFFORD

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And here comes Clifford to deny their bail.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Health and all happiness to my lord the king!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I thank thee, Clifford: say, what news with thee?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nay, do not fright us with an angry look;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: We are thy sovereign, Clifford, kneel again;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For thy mistaking so, we pardon thee.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: This is my king, York, I do not mistake;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: But thou mistakest me much to think I do:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To Bedlam with him! is the man grown mad?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, Clifford; a bedlam and ambitious humour

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Makes him oppose himself against his king.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He is a traitor; let him to the Tower,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And chop away that factious pate of his.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: He is arrested, but will not obey;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His sons, he says, shall give their words for him.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will you not, sons?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Ay, noble father, if our words will serve.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And if words will not, then our weapons shall.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Why, what a brood of traitors have we here!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Look in a glass, and call thy image so:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am thy king, and thou a false-heart traitor.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Call hither to the stake my two brave bears,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That with the very shaking of their chains

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They may astonish these fell-lurking curs:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Bid Salisbury and Warwick come to me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter the WARWICK and SALISBURY

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Are these thy bears? well bait thy bears to death.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And manacle the bear-ward in their chains,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: If thou darest bring them to the baiting place.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Oft have I seen a hot oerweening cur

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Run back and bite, because he was withheld;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who, being sufferd with the bears fell paw,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Hath clappd his tail between his legs and cried:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And such a piece of service will you do,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If you oppose yourselves to match Lord Warwick.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hence, heap of wrath, foul indigested lump,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: As crooked in thy manners as thy shape!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nay, we shall heat you thoroughly anon.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Take heed, lest by your heat you burn yourselves.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, Warwick, hath thy knee forgot to bow?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Old Salisbury, shame to thy silver hair,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou mad misleader of thy brain-sick son!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What, wilt thou on thy death-bed play the ruffian,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And seek for sorrow with thy spectacles?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, where is faith? O, where is loyalty?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If it be banishd from the frosty head,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Where shall it find a harbour in the earth?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wilt thou go dig a grave to find out war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And shame thine honourable age with blood?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why art thou old, and wantst experience?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Or wherefore dost abuse it, if thou hast it?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For shame! in duty bend thy knee to me

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That bows unto the grave with mickle age.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: My lord, I have considerd with myself

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The title of this most renowned duke;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And in my conscience do repute his grace

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: The rightful heir to Englands royal seat.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hast thou not sworn allegiance unto me?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: I have.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Canst thou dispense with heaven for such an oath?

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: It is great sin to swear unto a sin,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But greater sin to keep a sinful oath.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Who can be bound by any solemn vow

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To do a murderous deed, to rob a man,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To force a spotless virgins chastity,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To reave the orphan of his patrimony,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: To wring the widow from her customd right,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And have no other reason for this wrong

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: But that he was bound by a solemn oath?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A subtle traitor needs no sophister.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Call Buckingham, and bid him arm himself.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Call Buckingham, and all the friends thou hast,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am resolved for death or dignity.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The first I warrant thee, if dreams prove true.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: You were best to go to bed and dream again,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To keep thee from the tempest of the field.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I am resolved to bear a greater storm

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Than any thou canst conjure up to-day;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And that Ill write upon thy burgonet,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Might I but know thee by thy household badge.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, by my fathers badge, old Nevils crest,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The rampant bear chaind to the ragged staff,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This day Ill wear aloft my burgonet,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As on a mountain top the cedar shows

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That keeps his leaves in spite of any storm,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Even to affright thee with the view thereof.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And from thy burgonet Ill rend thy bear

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And tread it under foot with all contempt,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Despite the bear-ward that protects the bear.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And so to arms, victorious father,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To quell the rebels and their complices.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Fie! charity, for shame! speak not in spite,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For you shall sup with Jesu Christ to-night.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Foul stigmatic, thats more than thou canst tell.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If not in heaven, youll surely sup in hell.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: SCENE II. Saint Albans.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Alarums to the battle. Enter WARWICK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford of Cumberland, tis Warwick calls:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And if thou dost not hide thee from the bear,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, when the angry trumpet sounds alarum

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And dead mens cries do fill the empty air,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford, I say, come forth and fight with me:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Proud northern lord, Clifford of Cumberland,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Warwick is hoarse with calling thee to arms.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter YORK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, my noble lord? what, all afoot?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The deadly-handed Clifford slew my steed,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But match to match I have encounterd him

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And made a prey for carrion kites and crows

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Even of the bonny beast he loved so well.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter CLIFFORD

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Of one or both of us the time is come.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Hold, Warwick, seek thee out some other chase,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For I myself must hunt this deer to death.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then, nobly, York; tis for a crown thou fightst.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As I intend, Clifford, to thrive to-day,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: It grieves my soul to leave thee unassaild.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What seest thou in me, York? why dost thou pause?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With thy brave bearing should I be in love,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But that thou art so fast mine enemy.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Nor should thy prowess want praise and esteem,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: But that tis shown ignobly and in treason.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: So let it help me now against thy sword

speaker: YORK
text_entry: As I in justice and true right express it.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My soul and body on the action both!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A dreadful lay! Address thee instantly.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They fight, and CLIFFORD falls

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: La fin couronne les oeuvres.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Dies

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thus war hath given thee peace, for thou art still.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Peace with his soul, heaven, if it be thy will!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter YOUNG CLIFFORD

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shame and confusion! all is on the rout;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Fear frames disorder, and disorder wounds

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Where it should guard. O war, thou son of hell,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whom angry heavens do make their minister

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Throw in the frozen bosoms of our part

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hot coals of vengeance! Let no soldier fly.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: He that is truly dedicate to war

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hath no self-love, nor he that loves himself

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Hath not essentially but by circumstance

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: The name of valour.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Seeing his dead father

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: O, let the vile world end,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And the premised flames of the last day

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Knit earth and heaven together!

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Now let the general trumpet blow his blast,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Particularities and petty sounds

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To cease! Wast thou ordaind, dear father,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To lose thy youth in peace, and to achieve

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: The silver livery of advised age,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, in thy reverence and thy chair-days, thus

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To die in ruffian battle? Even at this sight

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: My heart is turnd to stone: and while tis mine,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: It shall be stony. York not our old men spares;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: No more will I their babes: tears virginal

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shall be to me even as the dew to fire,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: And beauty that the tyrant oft reclaims

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Shall to my flaming wrath be oil and flax.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Henceforth I will not have to do with pity:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Meet I an infant of the house of York,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Into as many gobbets will I cut it

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: As wild Medea young Absyrtus did:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: In cruelty will I seek out my fame.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, thou new ruin of old Cliffords house:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: As did AEneas old Anchises bear,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: So bear I thee upon my manly shoulders;

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: But then AEneas bare a living load,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Nothing so heavy as these woes of mine.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Exit, bearing off his father

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Enter RICHARD and SOMERSET to fight. SOMERSET is killed

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So, lie thou there;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For underneath an alehouse paltry sign,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The Castle in Saint Albans, Somerset

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Hath made the wizard famous in his death.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Sword, hold thy temper; heart, be wrathful still:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Priests pray for enemies, but princes kill.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exit

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Fight: excursions. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and others

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Away, my lord! you are slow; for shame, away!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can we outrun the heavens? good Margaret, stay.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What are you made of? youll nor fight nor fly:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Now is it manhood, wisdom and defence,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To give the enemy way, and to secure us

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: By what we can, which can no more but fly.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Alarum afar off

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If you be taen, we then should see the bottom

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Of all our fortunes: but if we haply scape,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As well we may, if not through your neglect,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: We shall to London get, where you are loved

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And where this breach now in our fortunes made

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: May readily be stoppd.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Re-enter YOUNG CLIFFORD

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: But that my hearts on future mischief set,

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: I would speak blasphemy ere bid you fly:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: But fly you must; uncurable discomfit

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Reigns in the hearts of all our present parts.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Away, for your relief! and we will live

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: To see their day and them our fortune give:

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Away, my lord, away!

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: SCENE III. Fields near St. Albans.

speaker: YOUNG CLIFFORD
text_entry: Alarum. Retreat. Enter YORK, RICHARD, WARWICK, and Soldiers, with drum and colours

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of Salisbury, who can report of him,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That winter lion, who in rage forgets

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Aged contusions and all brush of time,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, like a gallant in the brow of youth,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Repairs him with occasion? This happy day

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Is not itself, nor have we won one foot,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If Salisbury be lost.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: My noble father,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Three times to-day I holp him to his horse,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Three times bestrid him; thrice I led him off,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Persuaded him from any further act:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But still, where danger was, still there I met him;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And like rich hangings in a homely house,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So was his will in his old feeble body.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But, noble as he is, look where he comes.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Enter SALISBURY

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Now, by my sword, well hast thou fought to-day;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: By the mass, so did we all. I thank you, Richard:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: God knows how long it is I have to live;

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: And it hath pleased him that three times to-day

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: You have defended me from imminent death.

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Well, lords, we have not got that which we have:

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Tis not enough our foes are this time fled,

speaker: SALISBURY
text_entry: Being opposites of such repairing nature.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I know our safety is to follow them;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For, as I hear, the king is fled to London,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To call a present court of parliament.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let us pursue him ere the writs go forth.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What says Lord Warwick? shall we after them?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: After them! nay, before them, if we can.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, by my faith, lords, twas a glorious day:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Saint Albans battle won by famous York

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall be eternized in all age to come.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Sound drums and trumpets, and to London all:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And more such days as these to us befall!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Alarum. Enter YORK, EDWARD, RICHARD, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and Soldiers

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I wonder how the king escaped our hands.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While we pursued the horsemen of the north,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He slily stole away and left his men:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Cheerd up the drooping army; and himself,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Charged our main battles front, and breaking in

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Lord Staffords father, Duke of Buckingham,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Is either slain or wounded dangerously;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I cleft his beaver with a downright blow:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That this is true, father, behold his blood.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And, brother, heres the Earl of Wiltshires blood,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Whom I encounterd as the battles joind.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Throwing down SOMERSETs head

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thus do I hope to shake King Henrys head.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And so do I. Victorious Prince of York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Before I see thee seated in that throne

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This is the palace of the fearful king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And this the regal seat: possess it, York;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For this is thine and not King Henrys heirs

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For hither we have broken in by force.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Well all assist you; he that flies shall die.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thanks, gentle Norfolk: stay by me, my lords;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They go up

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And when the king comes, offer no violence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The queen this day here holds her parliament,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But little thinks we shall be of her council:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By words or blows here let us win our right.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Armd as we are, lets stay within this house.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The bloody parliament shall this be calld,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath made us by-words to our enemies.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I mean to take possession of my right.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Neither the king, nor he that loves him best,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The proudest he that holds up Lancaster,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ill plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, CLIFFORD, NORTHUMBERLAND, WESTMORELAND, EXETER, and the rest

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Even in the chair of state: belike he means,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Backd by the power of Warwick, that false peer,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And thine, Lord Clifford; and you both have vowd revenge

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: On him, his sons, his favourites and his friends.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: If I be not, heavens be revenged on me!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: What, shall we suffer this? lets pluck him down:

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Patience is for poltroons, such as he:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He durst not sit there, had your father lived.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My gracious lord, here in the parliament

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Let us assail the family of York.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, know you not the city favours them,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But when the duke is slain, theyll quickly fly.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Far be the thought of this from Henrys heart,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To make a shambles of the parliament-house!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall be the war that Henry means to use.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am thy sovereign.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am thine.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In following this usurping Henry.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: True, Clifford; and thats Richard Duke of York.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: It must and shall be so: content thyself.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster;

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That we are those which chased you from the field

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And slew your fathers, and with colours spread

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Marchd through the city to the palace gates.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And, by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Thy kinsman and thy friends, Ill have more lives

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Than drops of blood were in my fathers veins.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: As shall revenge his death before I stir.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will you we show our title to the crown?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am the son of Henry the Fifth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And seized upon their towns and provinces.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The lord protector lost it, and not I:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When I was crownd I was but nine months old.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Father, tear the crown from the usurpers head.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Lets fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Sound drums and trumpets, and the king will fly.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sons, peace!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Peace, thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And be you silent and attentive too,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For he that interrupts him shall not live.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thinkst thou that I will leave my kingly throne,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wherein my grandsire and my father sat?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No: first shall war unpeople this my realm;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, and their colours, often borne in France,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And now in England to our hearts great sorrow,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My titles good, and better far than his.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Twas by rebellion against his king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: [Aside]  I know not what to say; my titles weak.--

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tell me, may not a king adopt an heir?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What then?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: An if he may, then am I lawful king;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Richard, in the view of many lords,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Resignd the crown to Henry the Fourth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose heir my father was, and I am his.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He rose against him, being his sovereign,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And made him to resign his crown perforce.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstraind,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Think you twere prejudicial to his crown?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: No; for he could not so resign his crown

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But that the next heir should succeed and reign.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: [Aside]  All will revolt from me, and turn to him.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Plantagenet, for all the claim thou layst,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Thou art deceived: tis not thy southern power,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Can set the duke up in despite of me.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: May that ground gape and swallow me alive,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Do right unto this princely Duke of York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or I will fill the house with armed men,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And over the chair of state, where now he sits,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Write up his title with usurping blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: He stamps with his foot and the soldiers show themselves

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am content: Richard Plantagenet,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What wrong is this unto the prince your son!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What good is this to England and himself!

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Base, fearful and despairing Henry!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: How hast thou injured both thyself and us!

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: I cannot stay to hear these articles.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, cousin, let us tell the queen these news.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: In whose cold blood no spark of honour bides.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be thou a prey unto the house of York,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And die in bands for this unmanly deed!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or live in peace abandond and despised!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, CLIFFORD, and WESTMORELAND

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, Exeter!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why should you sigh, my lord?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But be it as it may: I here entail

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Conditionally, that here thou take an oath

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To honour me as thy king and sovereign,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And neither by treason nor hostility

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To seek to put me down and reign thyself.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This oath I willingly take and will perform.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Sennet. Here they come down

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Farewell, my gracious lord; Ill to my castle.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And Ill keep London with my soldiers.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And I unto the sea from whence I came.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Exeunt YORK, EDWARD, EDMUND, GEORGE, RICHARD,  WARWICK, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, their Soldiers, and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Ill steal away.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeter, so will I.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Who can be patient in such extremes?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, wretched man! would I had died a maid

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And never seen thee, never borne thee son,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or felt that pain which I did for him once,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or nourishd him as I did with my blood,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Rather than have that savage duke thine heir

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And disinherited thine only son.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Father, you cannot disinherit me:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: If you be king, why should not I succeed?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And given unto the house of York such head

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To entail him and his heirs unto the crown,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What is it, but to make thy sepulchre

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And creep into it far before thy time?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The duke is made protector of the realm;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And yet shalt thou be safe? such safety finds

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The trembling lamb environed with wolves.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Had I been there, which am a silly woman,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The soldiers should have tossd me on their pikes

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before I would have granted to that act.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But thou preferrst thy life before thine honour:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Until that act of parliament be repeald

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whereby my son is disinherited.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Will follow mine, if once they see them spread;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And utter ruin of the house of York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thus do I leave thee. Come, son, lets away;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our army is ready; come, well after them.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, to be murderd by his enemies.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: When I return with victory from the field

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Ill see your grace: till then Ill follow her.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exeunt QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor queen! how love to me and to her son

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hath made her break out into terms of rage!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Revenged may she be on that hateful duke,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The loss of those three lords torments my heart:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ill write unto them and entreat them fair.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. Sandal Castle.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter RICHARD, EDWARD, and MONTAGUE

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No, I can better play the orator.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But I have reasons strong and forcible.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter YORK

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why, how now, sons and brother! at a strife?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What is your quarrel? how began it first?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No quarrel, but a slight contention.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: About what?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: About that which concerns your grace and us;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The crown of England, father, which is yours.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Your right depends not on his life or death.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now you are heir, therefore enjoy it now:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: It will outrun you, father, in the end.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I took an oath that he should quietly reign.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But for a kingdom any oath may be broken:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I shall be, if I claim by open war.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ill prove the contrary, if youll hear me speak.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: An oath is of no moment, being not took

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Before a true and lawful magistrate,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That hath authority over him that swears:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Henry had none, but did usurp the place;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Then, seeing twas he that made you to depose,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Your oath, my lord, is vain and frivolous.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Therefore, to arms! And, father, do but think

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: How sweet a thing it is to wear a crown;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Within whose circuit is Elysium

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And all that poets feign of bliss and joy.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Why do we finger thus? I cannot rest

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Until the white rose that I wear be dyed

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Even in the lukewarm blood of Henrys heart.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Richard, enough; I will be king, or die.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Brother, thou shalt to London presently,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And whet on Warwick to this enterprise.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And tell him privily of our intent.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You Edward, shall unto my Lord Cobham,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With whom the Kentishmen will willingly rise:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In them I trust; for they are soldiers,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Witty, courteous, liberal, full of spirit.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While you are thus employd, what resteth more,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But that I seek occasion how to rise,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And yet the king not privy to my drift,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Nor any of the house of Lancaster?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But, stay: what news? Why comest thou in such post?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The queen with all the northern earls and lords

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Intend here to besiege you in your castle:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: She is hard by with twenty thousand men;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And therefore fortify your hold, my lord.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ay, with my sword. What! thinkst thou that we fear them?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My brother Montague shall post to London:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Let noble Warwick, Cobham, and the rest,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whom we have left protectors of the king,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: With powerful policy strengthen themselves,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And trust not simple Henry nor his oaths.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Brother, I go; Ill win them, fear it not:

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And thus most humbly I do take my leave.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter JOHN MORTIMER and HUGH MORTIMER

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: You are come to Sandal in a happy hour;

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: The army of the queen mean to besiege us.

speaker: JOHN MORTIMER
text_entry: She shall not need; well meet her in the field.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What, with five thousand men?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ay, with five hundred, father, for a need:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: A womans general; what should we fear?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: A march afar off

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I hear their drums: lets set our men in order,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And issue forth and bid them battle straight.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Five men to twenty! though the odds be great,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I doubt not, uncle, of our victory.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Many a battle have I won in France,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: When as the enemy hath been ten to one:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why should I not now have the like success?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alarum. Exeunt

speaker: YORK
text_entry: SCENE III. Field of battle betwixt Sandal Castle and Wakefield.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Alarums. Enter RUTLAND and his Tutor

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: Ah, whither shall I fly to scape their hands?

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: Ah, tutor, look where bloody Clifford comes!

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: Enter CLIFFORD and Soldiers

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Chaplain, away! thy priesthood saves thy life.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: As for the brat of this accursed duke,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whose father slew my father, he shall die.

speaker: Tutor
text_entry: And I, my lord, will bear him company.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Soldiers, away with him!

speaker: Tutor
text_entry: Ah, Clifford, murder not this innocent child,

speaker: Tutor
text_entry: Lest thou be hated both of God and man!

speaker: Tutor
text_entry: Exit, dragged off by Soldiers

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: How now! is he dead already? or is it fear

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: That makes him close his eyes? Ill open them.

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: So looks the pent-up lion oer the wretch

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: That trembles under his devouring paws;

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: And so he walks, insulting oer his prey,

speaker: RUTLAND

text_entry: In vain thou speakst, poor boy; my fathers blood

speaker: RUTLAND

text_entry: And hung their rotten coffins up in chains,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The sight of any of the house of York

speaker: CLIFFORD

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And till I root out their accursed line

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Lifting his hand

text_entry: O, let me pray before I take my death!

text_entry: Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just,

speaker: RUTLAND

speaker: RUTLAND
text_entry: And when I give occasion of offence,

speaker: RUTLAND

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: No cause!

speaker: CLIFFORD

text_entry: But that thy face is, vizard-like, unchanging,

text_entry: Made impudent with use of evil deeds,

text_entry: To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: SCENE I. A plain near Mortimers Cross in Herefordshire.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A march. Enter EDWARD, RICHARD, and their power

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I wonder how our princely father scaped,

text_entry: Or whether he be scaped away or no

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: From Cliffords and Northumberlands pursuit:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had he been taen, we should have heard the news;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had he been slain, we should have heard the news;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Or had he scaped, methinks we should have heard

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: The happy tidings of his good escape.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: How fares my brother? why is he so sad?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I cannot joy, until I be resolved

text_entry: Where our right valiant father is become.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I saw him in the battle range about;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And watchd him how he singled Clifford forth.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Methought he bore him in the thickest troop

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As doth a lion in a herd of neat;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or as a bear, encompassd round with dogs,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who having pinchd a few and made them cry,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So fared our father with his enemies;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So fled his enemies my warlike father:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Methinks, tis prize enough to be his son.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See how the morning opes her golden gates,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And takes her farewell of the glorious sun!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: How well resembles it the prime of youth,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Trimmd like a younker prancing to his love!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Not separated with the racking clouds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But severd in a pale clear-shining sky.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See, see! they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As if they vowd some league inviolable:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: In this the heaven figures some event.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I think it cites us, brother, to the field,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Each one already blazing by our meeds,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Should notwithstanding join our lights together

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And over-shine the earth as this the world.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whateer it bodes, henceforward will I bear

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Upon my target three fair-shining suns.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: You love the breeder better than the male.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ah, one that was a woful looker-on

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: When as the noble Duke of York was slain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your princely father and my loving lord!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Environed he was with many foes,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And stood against them, as the hope of Troy

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Against the Greeks that would have enterd Troy.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But Hercules himself must yield to odds;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And many strokes, though with a little axe,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hew down and fell the hardest-timberd oak.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By many hands your father was subdued;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But only slaughterd by the ireful arm

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Who crownd the gracious duke in high despite,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Laughd in his face; and when with grief he wept,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A napkin steeped in the harmless blood

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And after many scorns, many foul taunts,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They took his head, and on the gates of York

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They set the same; and there it doth remain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The saddest spectacle that eer I viewd.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Clifford, boisterous Clifford! thou hast slain

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: The flower of Europe for his chivalry;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And treacherously hast thou vanquishd him,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For hand to hand he would have vanquishd thee.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now my souls palace is become a prison:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Might in the ground be closed up in rest!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For never henceforth shall I joy again,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Never, O never shall I see more joy!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I cannot weep; for all my bodys moisture

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nor can my tongue unload my hearts great burthen;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For selfsame wind that I should speak withal
